body: Thanks for reporting this ! We are replacing cglib by byte-buddy, we'll see if we get the same warning (I'm expecting to).
@triceo It would be great, if you could give AssertJ `3.9.1` (which replaces `cglib` with `byte-buddy`) a try and check if the warnings still occur.

@PascalSchumacher Most of the warnings are indeed gone. I still occasionally get the following, though:

    WARNING: Illegal reflective access by org.assertj.core.api.AbstractSoftAssertions (file:/home/lpetrovi/.m2/repository/org/assertj/assertj-core/3.9.1/assertj-core-3.9.1.jar) to field java.lang.Throwable.detailMessage
    WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of org.assertj.core.api.AbstractSoftAssertions
    ...

The interesting bit is that it doesn't show up in the tests themselves. It shows up when the tests are being re-run with PITest (https://github.com/hcoles/pitest).
@PascalSchumacher The issue you reference has been closed, yet the warning is still there. Not sure what the next steps are here.

issue.title: Java 11 illegal reflective access operation using soft assertions

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary

I saw the earlier "resolved" issues with reflection in Java 9 and up, but this seems even more fundamental?

```
WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred
WARNING: Illegal reflective access by org.assertj.core.api.AbstractSoftAssertions ... to field java.lang.Throwable.detailMessage
```

#### Example

```java
SoftAssertions softly = new SoftAssertions();
softly.assertThat("x").isEqualTo("y");
softly.assertAll();
```

rename.from: Illegal reflective access warnings with SoftAssertions and Java 9
rename.to: Illegal reflective access warnings with SoftAssertions and Java 9+

body:
@triceo Sorry for the late response. #1036 did not remove access to the private field `Throwable#detailMessage` in https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/4946b0461fb240d437dd756b162dbf64c8402642/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractSoftAssertions.java#L176

As long as this is not fixed the warning `Illegal reflective access by org.assertj.core.api.AbstractSoftAssertions to field java.lang.Throwable.detailMessage` will continue to occur.
@PascalSchumacher is that something we can address ?

The easy solution would be to drop the line number feature of `SoftAssertions`.

There is no clean way to update the message of a `Throwable` and I am not aware of any other clean way to solve this problem.
I'm not familiar with the full codebase, but from looking at the codebase, couldn't `decorateErrorsCollected(...)` "rethrow" the errors, adding the line into the message of the newly created error?
@triceo that's something to try, I'm not too sure if you can keep the original stack trace though.
Can't you use Throwable#setStackTrace to add the original stack trace to the newly created error?
@PascalSchumacher would you have time to look into this ?
